div.head: Summary
div.p: Questions on Selflessness takes the form of a dialogue in which followers of the Mahāyāna tradition set out to dispel the doubts of non-Buddhists who first inquire about the meaning of selflessness. In the exchange that then follows, the Mahāyāna proponents also elucidate other key Buddhist doctrines such as the distinction between relative and ultimate reality, the origin of suffering, the emptiness and illusoriness of all phenomena, and the path that leads to awakening.

div.head: Acknowledgements
div.p: This text was translated, introduced, and edited by the Dharmasāgara Translation Group: Raktrul Ngawang Kunga Rinpoche, Rebecca Hufen, Shanshan Jia, Jason Sanche, and Arne Schelling. Thanks to Prof. Harunaga Isaacson (University of Hamburg) for his kind help and support.
The translation was completed under the patronage and supervision of 84000: Translating the Words of the Buddha.

Questions on Selflessness takes the form of a dialogue between followers of the Mahāyāna tradition and some non-Buddhist philosophers in which the Buddhists are first called upon to explain and defend their doctrine of selflessness. In the exchange that then follows, the proponents of the Mahāyāna point out some of the problems of categorically affirming or denying the existence of a self, and they go on to clarify some related Buddhist doctrines, such as the distinction between relative and ultimate reality, the illusory nature of perceptions, and the emptiness of all phenomena. The prose dialogue is followed by poetic verses that describe the causes for suffering and the continuous transmigration in cyclic existence, as well as the liberation that comes about through engendering the mind of awakening and the perfection of insight. The structure of the text deviates notably from the standard sūtra format, which presents an initial description of the setting and the audience of the discourse, the delivery of the discourse itself, and a conclusion extolling the benefits of the teaching. Instead, the text has no description of the setting or the audience or conclusion extolling its benefits, and its content consists not in the words of the Buddha himself, but of the anonymous followers of the Mahāyāna.

There does exist a Sanskrit manuscript, in addition to two Chinese translations of this sūtra (Taishō 846 and Taishō 1643). The Sanskrit, written in Newari script, is preserved in the National Archives of Nepal. NAK 3/693; NGMPP reel no. A 936-11(5). It has been edited, introduced, translated into French, and published by Lévi (1928). Another edition has been published by Vaidya (1961). For our translation we mainly compared the Tibetan text with the Sanskrit version. Because the Tibetan canonical versions of this text differ at many points from the extant Sanskrit text, we have assumed that the Tibetans were working with a quite different Sanskrit witness, and we therefore based our reading mainly on the Tibetan. The Sanskrit text did, nonetheless, help to clarify several passages, and we have occasionally deferred to readings in the Sanskrit that seemed more felicitous than the corresponding Tibetan. We have also noted some important differences between the Tibetan and Sanskrit versions in the notes.

We did observe a few notable variants in the Chinese translations. In the earliest Chinese translation (Taishō 846, 外道問聖大乘法無我義經, Wai dao wen sheng dasheng fa wuwo yi jing), which was prepared by Fa Tian (d. 1001) in the year 986, the sūtra begins rather differently than the Tibetan. Here the text starts with the usual opening phrase, “Thus did I hear at one time,” and we are moreover told that the Buddha is present within the assembly and is the one to whom the questions are asked. The other translation (Taishō 1643, 尼乾子問無我義經, Ni gan zi wen wuwo yi jing), which was prepared by Ri Cheng (1017–78) in the year 1063, has the same opening content as the Tibetan. But instead of employing the general designation “non-Buddhist,” the translation uses the more specific category of nirgrantha­jñāti­putras (尼乾子), which usually designates Jains. This epithet only exists in this later Chinese translation. The translator also attributes the text to Aśvaghoṣa and categorizes it as a treatise (śāstra), rather than a sūtra. This attribution has, however, been criticized by Lévi (1928) and Bhattacharya (1966).

As for the Tibetan translation, according to the colophon, it was prepared by the Indian scholar Kamalagupta and the great Tibetan translator Rinchen Sangpo. We can therefore assume that it was undertaken in the first half of the eleventh century, when these two scholars flourished. The first translation of this text from the Tibetan into a Western language was the French translation of Feer in 1883. The translation presented here is based on the Tibetan version in the Degé Kangyur, the comparative (dpe bsdur ma) edition of the Kangyur, and the Stok Palace manuscript.
Homage to all buddhas and bodhisattvas.

Now, the non-Buddhists—those who hold views based on objects and who engage in concepts and analysis—went among the followers of the Mahāyāna. Respectfully, with joined palms, they asked these questions on selflessness: “Sons of noble family, the Omniscient One taught that there is no self in the body. If there truly The Skt. reads paramātmā (“supreme soul/spirit”); however, the Tib. yang dag par (often for samyak, bhūte) is closer to paramārthe (“in reality”), which may indicate a variant in the copy of the Sanskrit text that the Tibetan translators followed. is no self in the body, then how do playfulness, laughter, crying, enjoyment, anger, pride, jealousy, calumny, and so forth come about? Is there truly a self in the body or not? It would be proper for you to dispel our doubts.”

The followers of the Mahāyāna replied, “Friends, it should not be said that there truly is or is not a self in the body, because to say in this case that there truly is or is not a self is mistaken speech. Now, if there were a self, then why is it not perceptible at all, even after searching through the hair, nails, teeth, “Teeth” (danta) is in the Skt. text, but not in the Tib. skin, head, flesh, bones, marrow, “Marrow” (Tib. rkang) is in the Tib., but not in the Skt. fat, ligaments, liver, intestines, throat, hands, feet, limbs, and other minor parts, both inside and outside the body?”
The non-Buddhists said, “The self is only visible to those who have the divine eye. How could it be visible to us who only have eyes of flesh?”

The followers of the Mahāyāna replied, “It is not seen even by those with the divine eye. For how can something that has no color, form, or shape be seen? The Skt. reads saṃskāra (“compound”); however, the Tib. is closer to saṃsthāna (“shape/form”).
The non-Buddhists said, “Then is it nonexistent?”

The followers of the Mahāyāna said, “Friends, to say that something is nonexistent We follow the Skt. reading, which makes the most sense here. The Tib. reads, “If it is said to be nonexistent, then to say it exists is wrong speech.” is mistaken speech. If it is nonexistent, then why do playfulness, laughter, crying, enjoyment, anger, pride, jealousy, calumny, and so forth arise so clearly? Therefore, it does not make sense to say that it is nonexistent. Given that it cannot be said to be existent or nonexistent, and that it is thus a fault to say either, it should not be said either that it exists or that it does not exist.”
The non-Buddhists asked, “Then what is apprehended in this case?”
The followers of the Mahāyāna said, “Nothing at all is apprehended.”
The non-Buddhists asked, “Is it as empty as the sky?”
The followers of the Mahāyāna said, “Friends, it is exactly like that! It is as empty as the sky.”
The non-Buddhists asked, “If that is so, then how should one view playfulness, laughter, crying, enjoyment, anger, pride, jealousy, calumny, and so forth?”
The followers of the Mahāyāna said, “They should be regarded as like an illusion, a dream, and a magical deception.”
The non-Buddhists asked, “How are they like an illusion, a dream, and a magical deception?”

The followers of the Mahāyāna said, “An illusion is a mere analogy. A dream is a mere appearance that is not graspable, empty by nature, and nonexistent in essence. A magical deception is intentionally fabricated. This is the way things are, friends. You should regard all these things as being like an illusion, a dream, and a magical deception.

“Moreover, the distinction between the relative and the ultimate should be pointed out. In this regard, the relative consists in the conception ‘this is self, that is other.’ To postulate a life force, a person, an individual, an agent, a feeler, wealth, children, wives, friends, relatives, and so forth is called the relative.

“Where there is no self, no other, no life force, no person, no individual, no agent, no feeler, no wealth, no sons, no wives, no friends, no relatives, and so forth, this is called the ultimate. Instead of “it is called the ultimate,” the Skt. reads sā madhyamā pratipattir (probably corrupted from pratipad) dharmāṇām (“This is the middle way of all phenomena”), which could, however, also refer to the sentence below: “This is the middle way teaching to strive for in practice.” It may be that our Sanskrit edition is incomplete here. The relative consists in habitually labeling all things, in the results of virtuous and nonvirtuous deeds, and in birth and cessation.

“The very essence of suchness, where there are no virtuous results, no nonvirtuous results, no birth, and no cessation, is beyond both pollution and purification. The passage “The relative consists in . . . and purification” is missing in the Skt. This is the middle way teaching to strive for in practice. In this regard, the following is said:

lg.l: The ultimate is beyond the worldly.
Sentient beings are overpowered by emotional defilements.
Not knowing the ultimate at all,
They wander around for a long time in saṃsāra.
Due to such unreal imaginings, We follow the Skt., which reads abhūta­pariklpanāt. The Tib. has only kun tu rtog pa de yis (omitting yang dag ma yin (abhūta-)).
Do not know the path of liberation. The Skt. reads, “Ordinary immature people, being blind / Do not see the path to liberation.”
Of unending suffering. The Skt. reads, “They are born and perish unceasingly in the five realms.”
Although birthless, they come and go.
Will rove around like a wheel.
In saṃsāra, the place of suffering,

They will revolve again and again. The two stanzas “Oblivious to the ultimate . . . They will revolve again and again” read in the Skt., “Fools, obscured by worldly phenomena, rove like a wheel. / Trapped in the net of saṃsāra, / Not knowing the ultimate where worldly existence perishes.”
“Just as the sun and the moon
Likewise, these beings, transmigrating in the world,
Come and go, again and again.
“The whole of saṃsāra The Skt. reads “all saṃskāras (‘conditioned or composite things’).” is impermanent and unstable,
That is why, by knowing the ultimate,
One abandons the state of relative reality.

As well as gandharvas, apsarases, and humans, The Tib. reads lha mi (“gods/devas and humans”). Since devas are already mentioned at the beginning, we opted for the Skt. reading apsaras. Here, however, “humans” is not mentioned. It could also be that lha mi is a corruption of lha mo (“goddess”), which comes closer to the Skt. rendering. Note that the Chinese has only “gandharva” (乾闥婆), which again points to variant versions of Sanskrit source texts.
All this is the result of the relative.
Kinnaras According to the Skt. The Tib. reads again dri za (gandharva). and mahoragas,
Go again and again to hell—
All this is the result of the relative.
In god realms and other havens of good qualities.
Their transmigration and fall from the higher realms
Is all the result of the relative. This verse is missing in the Skt.
Of Śakra or of a universal monarch
Will once again enter the birthplace of animals—
All this is the result of the relative.

“Abandoning the great bliss According to the Skt. mahāsukha. The Tib. reads bden pa bzang po (“pleasant reality/truth”). The Tib. bden pa (“reality/truth”) could be a corruption of bde ba (sukha, “bliss”).
Of the devas of the higher realms,
On the mind of awakening, luminosity.
Such is the definition of the mind of awakening.
Such is the definition of the mind of awakening.

Such is the definition of the mind of awakening. The Skt. has two more stanzas here: “Neither white nor red, / Neither dark blue nor yellow, / Without color or form— / Such is the definition of the mind of awakening. / Without transformation or manifestation, / Without antagonism or bondage, / Without form, like the sky— / Such is the definition of the mind of awakening.”
And having the perfection of insight as its nature Here we follow the Skt., which reads rūpam (“nature/form”). The Tib. reads sbyor (“application/engagement”).—
Such is the definition of the mind of awakening.
“Beyond analogy, it is nothing to meditate on.
Such is the definition of the mind of awakening.
They are similar to magical illusions and mirages.
Is not visible after even a moment,
So the supreme state should be cultivated

With such a view of the perfection of insight. Since the Tib. here is not clear to us, this verse has been translated according to the Skt. abhrāntare yathā vidyut kṣaṇādapi na dṛśyate | prajñā­pāramitādṛṣṭyā bhāvayetparamaṃ padam ||. The meaning of the Skt. verse seems to be that all the illusory things mentioned in the preceding two stanzas vanish all at once (like the flash of lightning in a cloud) with the realization of the perfection of insight. The Tib. reads ji ltar nang na thig le ni / skad cig de la mi mthong ste / shes rab pha rol phyin mthong na / de bzhin blo ni ’dus ma bya.
The enjoyment of material things, and so forth
Dreams are imaginings of the mind.
Mind itself is like the sky.
It is the way of the perfection of insight.
Will become free of all reified entities
And will attain the highest state.

Will gain the fruit of Mahāyāna.” The Skt. has nirvāṇa. The corresponding Skt. passage reads, “As many faults as relative reality has, / Just as many virtues does nirvāṇa have. / Nirvāṇa is nonarising; / It is unstained by any faults. // Then the non-Buddhists, being satisfied, became free from conceptualization, and having concentrated on the practice, they acquired the wisdom of the Mahāyāna” (yāvantaḥ saṃvṛterdoṣāstāvanto nirvṛterguṇāḥ | nirvṛtiḥ syādanutpattiḥ sarva­doṣairna lipyate || atha te tīrthikāstuṣṭā vikalpa­rahitāstadā bhāvanāṃ samādhāya mahāyānaya­jñalābhino'bhūvanniti || mahāyāna­nirdeśe nairātmya­paripṛcchā samāptā ||).

gloss.term: A follower of a non-Buddhist religious system or philosophy.
The sixth of the six perfections, it refers to the profound understanding of the emptiness of all phenomena, the realization of ultimate reality.

A class of semidivine beings who haunt or protect forests, rivers, and other natural spaces, or serve as guardians to villages and towns. They are traditionally propitiated for health, wealth, protection, and other boons.

A class of semidivine beings who are famous for wielding (dhara) spells (vidyā). Loosely understood as “sorcerers,” these magical beings are frequently petitioned through dhāraṇī and Kriyātantra ritual to grant magical powers to the supplicant. The later Buddhist tradition, playing on the dual valences of vidyā as “spell” and “knowledge,” began to apply this term to realized figures in the Buddhist pantheon.
An accomplished being; a class of semidivine beings.

Literally “large serpent.” A semidivine being that takes the form of a large serpent, sometimes with a human torso and head. They are a class of subterranean geomantic spirits whose movement through the seasons and months of the year is deemed significant for construction projects.

In Indian religious mythology, a class of nonhuman beings who often appear as semidivine celestial musicians. The same term is used in certain Buddhist texts in a quite different sense: to denote a disembodied sentient being or anguished spirit in the intermediate state between two lives, seeking the conditions for a new birth as a human or other kind of embodied being.
Popular figures in Indian culture, apsarases are said to be goddesses of the clouds and water and to be wives of the gandharvas.
A semidivine being, half horse, half human, also often described as a celestial musician.
Selflessness denotes the lack of inherent existence in self-identity and also, more subtly, in all physical and mental phenomena.
A term used to express the absence of any intrinsic essence in all phenomena.

Refers in this text to the Buddhist distinction between relative and ultimate. Relative reality refers to the world of reified entities that are believed to have essential existence, whereas ultimate reality refers to the emptiness or lack of inherent existence in all phenomena.
An Indian scholar who was involved in a number of translations during the eleventh century in Tibet.
A famous Tibetan translator who lived from 958 to 1055 ce. He was mainly active in western Tibet, especially at Tholing monastery.
An alternative name for Indra, lord of the gods, who, according to Buddhist cosmology, resides in the Heaven of the Thirty-Three.
